=====Idioms=====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|覆水盆に返らず|ふくすい ぼん に かえらず}}: “spilt water does not return to the basin” → some things cannot be [[undone]]
* {{ja-r|盆を覆す|ぼん を くつがえす}}: “to knock over the pots” → said of heavy rain; compare {{m|en|raining pitchforks and hammer handles}}, {{m|en|raining cats and dogs}}
* {{ja-r|盆を傾ける|ぼん を かたむける}}: “to make the pots lean over” → said of heavy rain; compare {{m|en|raining pitchforks and hammer handles}}, {{m|en|raining cats and dogs}}
* {{ja-r|盆に載せたる蟇|ぼん に のせたる ひきがえる}}: “a toad placed on a tray” → a metaphor for being [[at a loss]] and unable to proceed, much as a toad on a tray will [[slip]] about and be unable to get [[traction]]
* {{ja-r|塗り盆に載せた蛙|ぬりぼん に のせた かえる}}: “a frog placed on a lacquered tray” → a metaphor for being [[at a loss]] and unable to proceed, much as a frog on a lacquered tray will [[slip]] about and be unable to get [[traction]]
* {{ja-r|塗り盆へ載せた蟇蛙|ぬりぼん へ のせた ひきがえる}}: “a toad placed on a lacquered tray” → a metaphor for being [[at a loss]] and unable to proceed, much as a toad on a lacquered tray will [[slip]] about and be unable to get [[traction]]
* {{ja-r|盆を敷く|ぼん を しく}}: “to lay the mats” → to start [[gambling]]; to establish one's own [[household]]
* {{ja-r|盆をひく|ぼん を ひく}}: “to lay the mats” → to start [[gambling]]; to establish one's own [[household]]
* {{ja-r|盆を戴きて天を望む|ぼん を いただきて てん を のぞむ}}: “to look at the sky with a pot [or tray] on one's head” → a metaphor for two things that cannot be done at the same time, much as carrying a pot or tray on one's head would prevent one from looking up
{{der-bottom}}

===Etymology 2===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|お盆|お盆 (Obon)}}
[[File:Mukaebi_20120731.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|盆}}: [[Obon]]. Lighting the welcome [[beacon]]s in [[w:Numazu,_Shizuoka|Numazu]], [[w:Shizuoka_Prefecture|Shizuoka Prefecture]].]]
{{wikipedia|Bon Festival}}
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|ぼん|yomi=o}}
Short for {{m|ja|盂蘭盆|tr=Urabon}} or {{m|ja|盂蘭盆会|tr=Urabon'e}}, from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=ほん'}} {{m|ltc|盂蘭盆|tr=hju lan bwon}} or {{m|ltc|盂蘭盆會|tr=hju lan bwon hwaj<sup>H</sup>}} (compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} {{zh-l|盂蘭盆|tr=yúlánpén}} or {{zh-l|盂蘭盆會|tr=yúlánpénhuì}}), a transcription of {{etyl|pi|ja|sort=ほん'}} {{m|pi|sc=Deva|उल्लुम्पन|tr=ullumpana||raising, helping}}, noun inflection of {{etyl|pi|-}} verb {{m|pi|sc=Deva|उल्लुम्पयति|tr=ullumpayati||to raise up, to help}}.

A number of Japanese dictionaries state that this term derives from {{cog|sa|sc=Deva|उल्लम्बन|tr=ullambana}}, purportedly meaning “hanging upside-down” in reference to the souls of the dead being tortured in hell by being strung up by their feet.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref><ref>{{R:Shinmeikai5}}</ref> However, the {{etyl|sa|-}} word would be the noun inflection of verb {{m|sa|sc=Deva|उल्लम्बयति|tr=ullambayati||to hang something up}}, with no inherent “upside-down” meaning. Moreover, the purported {{etyl|sa|-}} term's meaning of “hanging upside-down” does not match very well, given that the ''urabon'' ceremonies are about helping the dead. And lastly, Buddhism was transmitted by speakers of {{etyl|pi|-}}. All of this suggests that explanations of the dead hanging upside-down in hell are more likely to be [[folk etymologies]] based on a mistaken connection to {{etyl|sa|-}}, rather than a more direct semantic link to {{etyl|pi|-}}.

{{der-bottom}}

=====Idioms=====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|盆と正月が一緒に来たよう|^ぼん と ^しょうがつ が いっしょ に きた よう}}: “as if Bon and New Years came together” → extremely busy; an overlap of multiple happy occasions
* {{ja-r|盆と正月が一時に来たよう|^ぼん と ^しょうがつ が いっとき に きた よう}}: “as if Bon and New Years came at the same time” → extremely busy; an overlap of multiple happy occasions
* {{ja-r|盆の十六日は地獄の釜の蓋が開く|^ぼん の じゅうろく にち は じごく の かま の ふた が あく}}: “on the 16th day of Bon, the lids on the kettles of hell open up” → from a tradition that the 16th day of July (the day just after Obon) is a day of rest and relative peace for the souls of the damned, when the demons of hell temporarily let people off the hook, and employers in this world would give their employees a day off
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての鯖商い|^ぼん すぎて の さば あきない}}: “the mackeral business after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that grilled mackeral was often given as a gift food item or as an [[offering]] during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての蓮の葉|^ぼん すぎて の はす の .は}}: “a [[lotus]] leaf after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that lotus leaves would often be used in [[offering]]s during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての蓮の花|^ぼん すぎて の はす の はな}}: “a [[lotus]] blossom after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that lotus flowers would often be used in [[offering]]s during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆三日は嫁と姑が仲よくなる|^ぼん みっか は よめ と しゅうとめ が なかよく なる}}: “brides and mothers-in-law (can) get along for the three days of Bon” → from how family and other guests come to visit during [[Obon]]; compare the famous {{w|Benjamin Franklin}} quote, “After three days men grow weary of a wench, a guest, and weather rainy.”
{{der-bottom}}
